articles.name: Freshteam - HackerRank Integration Guide
articles.title: Freshteam - HackerRank Integration Guide
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank integrates with Freshteam for screening Tests. The integration between HackerRank and Freshteam allows hiring teams to send HackerRank assessments and view candidate scores, directly through the Freshteam platform. This reduces friction by eliminating the need to switch between multiple platforms, thus saving time, eliminating cognitive bias, and bringing more order to your recruiting.

Tests Features

Below is a list of features that the HackerRank - Freshteam Integration offers:

Feature Freshteam
View the Full list of HackerRank Tests
Invite candidates to a specific test
Cancel an invite
Reinvite
Status update from invite to completion
View Total Candidate Score
View Maximum Score
Link to the detailed test report
View Question-wise scores
View Candidate Feedback
View Reviewer Comments
View Code
Play Code
Templates user default
Invite sent from assigned recruiter on requisition
Public URL sync
Update results after editing HackerRank
Result sharing and validity
Add Time Accommodation

Interviews or Code Pair

Feature Freshteam
Create CodePair link
Schedule CodePair Interview
View Result
View Scorecard
Link to the detailed report

Reaching Out for the Integration Help

To know more about how to integrate the Freshteam ATS with HackerRank, you can reach out to the HackerRank point of contact or raise a support request by writing to support@hackerrank.com.

You can also refer to the Freshteam ATS support articles.

articles.name: Using Templates in Interviews
articles.title: Using Templates in Interviews
articles.body:
Log in as an interviewer and click on the Question Library option from the interview starting page.

  • You can select a question from the question library and click on the + icon to add it to a template.

  • You can either add a question to a pre-existing template by clicking the checkbox next to an existing template or click to create a new template.
  • Click on Create new template and enter the template name to create a template.

Updating Interview Templates

  • You can access the templates from the left pane of the interview page.

  • All the templates created by you and shared with you will be available here. 
  • You can click on the desired template name to open it.

Rename a Template

  • You can rename the template by clicking on the edit icon below.

Note: You can only rename the templates created by you.

Selecting a Job Role for Template

  • You can select a suitable job role for the template from the Role section drop-down menu, as shown below.

Note: Your templates will be shared with all your teams by default.

Edit/View Access of a Template

You can give view/edit access to the teams by selecting the desired option, as shown below. 

All My Teams Can Edit: This will allow your team to collaborate on the list of questions in the template. The team members will be able to add and remove questions from the template.

Suggestion: Use this to collaborate with your team and create a standardized set of questions to ask while hiring for a particular role!

All my teams can View: This will allow your team only to view the list of questions in the template. The team members will not be able to add and remove questions from the template.

Removing a Question from the Template 

  • You can remove a question from the template by clicking the (-) icon next to the question inside the template.

Launching a Question from Template to Interview

  • You can launch any question from a template to an interview by clicking on the Use icon.  
  • For templates consisting of five or fewer questions, you can use all questions at once by clicking the Use All button.

Deleting a Template 

If you want to delete a template created by you, you can do that by following the below steps: 

  • Click on the three dots in the top right corner and select Delete Template.

  • Select Delete from the pop-up window. This will delete the template.

Note: You can not delete the templates created by others.

articles.name: HackerRank - Eightfold Integration User Guide
articles.title: HackerRank - Eightfold Integration User Guide
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank Tests integrate with Eightfold to trigger invites to candidates directly from the Eightfold Recruiting portal. Recruiters managing candidate profiles in Eightfold can use this integration to seamlessly carry out skill assessments of candidates for different job requisitions. Candidates receive the HackerRank Test and Interview invites and take up the challenges. Once done, the candidate's score and performance data is automatically available in Eightfold for further evaluation.

This article describes the steps to trigger HackerRank Test and interview invites to candidates from Eightfold.

The workflow to assess candidates with the HackerRank - Eightfold integration is as follows:

  1. Create Tests in the HackerRank platform with the required roles for Eightfold.
  2. Select the appropriate candidate in the Eightfold platform and send the HackerRank Test to the candidate. You must move the candidate to the respective stage defined by your organization to trigger an assessment.
  3. View the results within Eightfold after the candidate attempts their Test.
  4. Schedule an Interview from the Eightfold platform by moving the candidate to the respective interview stage requiring a remote technical interview via HackerRank.
  5. View the performance of the candidate as a report on Eightfold.

Sending HackerRank Test Invites from Eightfold

  1. In the Eightfold platform, click Positions to view all the positions available.
  2. Select the required position for which you want to send the Test to a candidate.
  3. Click the Leads tab.
  4. Select the appropriate candidate whom you want to assess.
  5. You can view the candidate details in the right pane.
  6. From the Advance Stage drop-down, select the appropriate stage to send the assessment to a candidate. For example, to send the assessments to candidates, select the Recruiter Screen.
  7. The Confirm ATS Action is displayed which allows you to select an assessment.
  8. After you select the Test, click Confirm. The selected Test is sent to the candidate.
  9. An email invite is sent to the candidate's account. The email invite template is pulled from the default template set on HackerRank by the recruiter. For more information about the invite templates, see Email Templates.

  10. The candidate must click Start Test to start the test. The candidate is then redirected to the HackerRank platform login.

  11. After a candidate completes the test, the Test status is updated on HackerRank.

    The Recruiter can view the reports of the candidate's assessments on HackerRank.

Viewing the Candidate Test Report on Eightfold

  1. Once the candidate takes this assessment, the results are displayed on the candidate's profile in the Eightfold platform.
  2. Click View Report to view the candidate's reports. The report is displayed on the HackerRank platform.

Scheduling HackerRank Interviews from Eightfold

After you pass a candidate based on the assessment, you can promote the candidate to the Interview stage to conduct or schedule online coding interviews. You can schedule the interview from the Eightfold platform and leverage the HackerRank Interviews to assess a candidate based on their skills. The HackerRank Interview is an efficient tool for recruiters and technical managers to conduct interactive coding interviews with candidates located remotely.

This results in a seamless recruiting experience for the hiring managers and recruiters, and the results are directly displayed on the Eightfold platform.

Scheduling an HackerRank Interview from Eightfold

To schedule an interview from Eightfold, perform the following:

  1. Select the candidate that you want to schedule an interview with and move the candidate to the appropriate stage, such as an Onsite Interview.
  2. The Confirm ATS Action window is displayed.
  3. Click Confirm. The candidate is advanced or promoted to the Onsite Interview stage.
  4. To schedule the interview, click the Schedule drop-down and select Schedule A Meeting.
  5. The Schedule a Meeting window is displayed.
  6. Select the appropriate interview Template.
  7. Provide the appropriate details to schedule the interview such as the interviewer name and email ID, the mode of video conferencing, and so on.
  8. Select HackerRank Interview from the Live Coding drop-down list.
  9. Click Next - Scheduling Options.
  10. Select the time and date of the interview.
  11. Click Next - Communication. The Scheduling Communications tab displays details about the template that will be sent to the candidate as a mail.
  12. The interview schedule is also displayed.
  13. After you review all the details, click Send Invite to send the interview invitation to the candidate.
  14. The scheduled interview is displayed on the candidate's profile.
  15. Interview links are sent to both the interviewer and candidate email.
  16. As an interviewer, access the interview link and log in to the session with your HackerRank for Work account. For more information on conducting coding interviews, refer to Conducting a HackerRank Interview.

Viewing the Candidate HackerRank Interview Report on Eightfold

  1. After you complete the HackerRank interview with the candidate, the results are displayed as a report on the candidate's profile in Eightfold.
  2. Click the View Report link to view the candidate's detailed report on HackerRank.

Recommended Articles

  • Understanding the HackerRank Interview interface

  • Logging in to a HackerRank Interview Session

  • Interview Preparation Checklist for Candidates

articles.name: HackerRank Certified Assessments
articles.title: HackerRank Certified Assessments
articles.body:
Overview

Aiming to help recruiters to fasten their screening process HackerRank comes up with standardized role-specific tests that reduce the recruiter's dependency on the engineering team in their hiring process and create an unbiased testing environment. 

What is a Certified Assessment? 

HackerRank Certified Assessments are pre-built role-specific tests created after long-term research and analysis of the questions that match the industry standards for the given role and assure a quality outcome from the screening process. 

These certified tests follow the industry norms and design a single test for a specific role, and any company that wants to hire for that role can use this single test to assess their candidates. This provides an unbiased interview experience for both the companies and the candidates.

Benefits

  • 100% Managed Screening: The internal team of HackerRank entirely manages these assessments. You do not have to depend upon the recruiting and engineering teams to create the test questions or manage the test.  
  • Unbiased Assessments: HackerRank uses a third-party content bias checker that helps us to provide an unbiased assessment experience.  
  • Leakage Protected Skill Bundles: You will not be required to keep a tab on your tests to check if a question is being leaked. HackerRank automatically detects and removes the leaked questions from the system and replaces them with new questions.  
  • Robust Plagiarism Detection: HackerRank provides the market's most powerful plagiarism detection software to detect any malpractice being committed.  
  • Accurate Classification: Our team has built a machine-learning-powered role mapping engine that conducts in-depth research by scanning thousands of job descriptions throughout the industry. This approach helps us accurately list the skills required for a specific job role. 
  • No Repetition: HackerRank follows a 10-step robust evaluation process to select questions. The possibility of two developers getting the same question is 1 in 1000.  

Creating a Certified Assessment 

  • Click on the Create Test option and select the role you want to assess the candidates. 
  • Search for the desired role or the skill  you want to assess. If the role you have selected has a Certified Assessment you can see the badge as shown in the below picture. 
  • A certified assessment is categorized into skill-based sections. You can see the skills mapped to the role you have selected. You can add or remove these roles in the next step.

Tip: You can access the HackerRank Roles Directory to view the skills mapped to each role.

  • On the test page, you can access the details such as selected role, core skills mapped to that role and other relevant skills. You can click on the + icon beside the relevant skills to add them to your assessment.  

Section Level Settings

Shuffling Sections

You have the flexibility to rearrange the order of skill bundles within a test. To reorder the skill bundles, simply hover your mouse cursor over a skill bundle, and while keeping the mouse button pressed, drag the skill bundle upwards or downwards to the desired position. This allows you to easily shuffle and reorder the sequence of skill bundles as per your preference within the test.

Skill Bundle Settings

  • Hover over the skill section and click on the settings icon 
  • Within the skill section settings you can change its name, select the number of questions for it and change the time limit to answer that section.  
  • From the Advanced Settings you can: 
    • Control if you want the candidates to see the sections. When disabled candidates will only see the questions within a test.  
    • Enable or disable the sections to be shuffled for the candidates. 
    • Allow or disallow the candidates to revisit previous sections once answered.  
    • Allow the candidates to use the duration left in previous sections for the upcoming sections.  

Note: You must add duration to each section to enable the above three settings.   

 

Customizing The Skills 

Coming to customization, if you feel that a present skill is not needed for the role you are hiring or want to test an additional skill in the candidates, you can customize the assessment at the skill level.  

Important: When you add or remove a skill the test will lose its Certified Assessment status

Adding a New Skill

  •  Click on Add New+ and select from the available options: 
    • Add Skill Based Questions: Add questions curated by HackerRank  mapped to each skill.
    • Add Manually: Add questions from HackerRank or My Company library. 

  • If you select Add Skill Based Questions you will be asked to choose the skills.
  • There are two types of skill bundles: 
    • Basic Skill Bundles:
      • These are standard skill bundles. The questions in these bundles are mapped to specific skills. These bundles are not protected from leakage. In case of a question leak you have to manually change that question within the test. 
    • Leak Protected Skill Bundles: You can identify one with 
      • The questions in these skill bundles are safeguarded against leakage 
      • HackerRank manages these skill bundles exclusively. If any questions from these bundles are leaked, HackerRank replaces the compromised questions with new ones.
      • Leak protected skill bundles are highlighted with the safeguard icon as shown below. 

  • The skills are differentiated at three levels: 
    • Basic: Consists of questions with easy difficulty. 
    • Intermediate: Consists of questions with medium difficulty.
    • Advanced: Consists of questions with Hard difficulty. 
  • Next, you can choose the Question Type, such as Coding, MCQ, or Project.

 

  • After selecting the desired Skill and Question type, click the add to the test. You can view that your selected skill is now present in your test as a new section. 

  • When you add a new skill section, the duration of your test will also change according to it. 

Adding Questions From Library

  • Select the add manually option after clicking Add New+
  • Select Add From Library or Create Question option.  

  • When you select Add From Library you will be taken to the HackerRank library where you can select the desired question using the available filtering options. Click on the plus icon to add the question.  Selected questions will appear on the left pane of the screen. 

 

  • Once done you can click on Go Back to Test to proceed with the test. Selected questions are added as a section.   

Skill Bundle Settings

  • Hover over the skill section and click on the settings icon 
  • Within the skill section settings you can change its name, select the number of questions for it and change the time limit to answer that section.  
  • From the Advanced Settings you can: 
    • Control if you want the candidates to see the sections. When disabled candidates will only see the questions within a test.  
    • Enable or disable the sections to be shuffled for the candidates. 
    • Allow or disallow the candidates to revisit previous sections once answered.  
    • Allow the candidates to use the duration left in previous sections for the upcoming sections.  

Note: You must add duration to each section to enable the above three settings.   

Removing a Skill Section

Hover your cursor over the skill you want to remove and click the delete icon. This will remove that skill section you chose.

Once done you can Publish the test and start inviting the candidates.

Note: Copy-paste tracking is turned on by default. You can not change it.  Similarly, the shuffle sections too is a default setting that cannot be changed.  

Certified Assessments allow you to set up the skills weightage and cutoff score for your assessments.  You can know how that functionality works from here.

articles.name: Audio and Video Calls in Interviews Powered by Zoom
articles.title: Audio and Video Calls in Interviews Powered by Zoom
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank Interviews have an inbuilt audio and video call functionality for the Interviewers and Candidates to interact with each other during the interview. To enhance this functionality, HackerRank joined with Zoom, a well-known video telephony software that provides a seamless communication experience for its users.

HackerRank Interviews, now powered by Zoom, aims to provide this same seamless experience. 

Note: This feature is currently supported on Chrome, Microsoft Edge, and Firefox. The latest versions of browsers are recommended for a hassle-free experience. 

Prerequisites

  • To have this working, ensure that your organization has not blocked these URLs:
    • *.zoom.us
    • *.*.zoom.us
    • zoom.us

Compatibility Check for Tests and Interviews

You can check your connectivity status on the HackerRank Compatibility tool of HackerRank.

This tool checks the audio/video permissions, internet strength, device type, Window size, browser compatibility, and other parameters.

If you face any problem accessing the above domain, you can reach out to support@hackerrank.com with a screenshot of the error message. 

  • The Zoom experience in HackerRank Interviews works in such a way that you need not have a Zoom account or install any software. Once you initiate the call in an interview, it is connected through Zoom automatically. 

Benefits of HackerRank Interviews powered by Zoom 

  • HackerRank Interviews powered by Zoom enables you to connect your calls within seconds without lag.  
  • Network drops and slow internet connections are very common. One of the main benefits of Interviews powered by Zoom is that the call quality works fine even with a slow internet connection.  
  • We recommend you turn your video off in case of any issues with the audio quality. 
  • In case of a network drop, calls will reconnect automatically if your connection resumes within 2 minutes.

articles.name: Question Insights
articles.title: Question Insights
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank provides insights into every question, which helps the recruiters to analyze the performance of each question under multiple parameters. Various fields in the insights will help you understand the candidates’ approach and success rate in solving a particular question. Using this analysis you can select suitable questions for your test.  

View Question Insights

Prerequisites

  • The question must be used at least once in a test.  

Steps

  1. Navigate to the library and hover your mouse over the required question. 
  2. Click on the Insights option to view the Question Insights dashboard.

This dashboard comprises of the following:

Question Details

This section provides details about the question e.g. name and author of the question, date when question was created, recommended time to answer the question, source of question and more. 

Question Score Distribution

The score distribution graph elaborates the distribution of the score percentage of Candidates who attempted a response to this question.

Question Percentiles

This section provides details about the score obtained by the total percentage of candidates who attempted the questions.

  • Median Score: 50% of the candidates who attempted the question scored less than or equal to the number mentioned.
  • 75th Percentile Score: 75% of the candidates who attempted the question scored less than or equal to the number mentioned.
  • 90th Percentile Score: 90% of the candidates who attempted the question scored less than or equal to the number mentioned.

Question Activities

  • Attempts: Number of the candidates who attempted the question.
  • Median Attempt Time: 50% of the candidates who attempted this question took less than or equal to the time mentioned. 
  • Average Score Percentage: Number of attempts made by the candidates.
  • Median Time to Full Score: 50% of the candidates who scored 100% answering this question took less than or equal to the time mentioned.

Question Usage

This section explains the number of Candidates who attempted to answer this question per month from its inception to date. The section also includes the top languages used for the question.

  • Distribution of Candidates Over Time: Number of candidates attempted to answer this question per month from its inception to the date.
  • Top 10 Languages by Attempts: The top ten languages used by the candidates for attempting the question.

Question Language Stats 

This section shows a statistical table of languages used by the candidates that includes Language by Median Score percentage, Language by Maximum Score Attained, and Language by Median Time Taken.

Downloading Data 

You can download the data from any tile by clicking on the hamburger icon and selecting the desired file format.  You can also view that widget in full screen upon clicking View in full screen option, and refresh the data by selecting refresh.

articles.name: Configuring the Test Integrity Settings
articles.title: Configuring the Test Integrity Settings
articles.body:
As a recruiter, you can configure the Test integrity features and enable the options available according to your requirements. HackerRank provides

various options to ensure that Candidates are prevented from cheating while taking Tests and thus maintaining the integrity of the Test.

You can configure the Proctoring and Shuffle settings from the Test Integrity tab.

Configure Proctoring

HackerRank for Work provides the ability to monitor Candidates’ focus on the Test screen while they are attempting Tests, referred to as Proctoring. Through proctoring, recruiters can assess their Candidates’ authenticity and note any suspicious activities or malpractices during the Test.

You can Proctor the remote assessments in HackerRank. HackerRank provides multiple proctoring options. 

  • Copy/Paste proctoring: This will help you monitor if the candidate is pasting the code from other sources, including the detection of copy-pasted code from ChatGPT. 
  • Tab Proctoring: This feature will help you monitor if the candidate switches between tabs during the test.  
  • Photo Identification: With the help of this feature, you can make sure that the correct candidate is taking the test.  
  • Image Proctoring: With this feature, you can monitor the candidate during the test with the help of a webcam.  
    • Image Analysis: With image analysis, candidates’ webcam photos will be analyzed to flag for any suspicious activity. This feature uses artificial intelligence. Customers are responsible for any laws applying to them when using this feature. Learn more about Image Analysis.
  • Watermarking: With this feature, you can add watermarks on the questions inside a test. Enabling this feature would add the logged-in user's email ID as a watermark on the question section of the assessment page. Learn more about Watermarking The Tests. 
  • Multiple Monitor Detection: With this feature, you can detect if an external monitor is connected to the device on which the candidate is taking an assessment. Learn more about Multiple Monitor Detection 
  • AI Plagiarism Detection:  AI plagiarism detection system feeds several proctoring and user-generated signals into a supervised Machine Learning algorithm to flag suspicious behavior during an assessment. By understanding code iterations made by the candidate, the model can detect if they had external help, including from ChatGPT. Learn more about our AI-Powered Plagiarism Detection.

Note: You can enable only one of Photo Identification or Image Proctoring option, not both. 

You can enable these features in the Test Integrity settings by scrolling down the page and clicking the toggle switch to enable the desired proctoring option under the Proctoring section. Once selected, click Save Changes to enable the proctoring for your test. 

Proctoring the Tests

Learn more about Proctoring HackerRank Tests here. 

Note: When proctoring is enabled, the Candidates will not be able to see any change. They will be able to utilize features like autocomplete and linting, and so on. 

Configuring Shuffle Settings

The Shuffle Settings allow users to shuffle questions. This is to ensure that the questions are shuffled so that Candidates are not presented with the same order of questions. This prevents Candidates who are taking the same test from collaborating and perform cheating. Thus maintaining the integrity of the Tests.

Shuffle Questions

The Shuffle Questions option allows the Candidates to view questions in random order.

The Questions tab that contains all the Question settings redirects to this option for shuffling the Questions.

Question Settings

The Hide Question Title lets you disallow candidates from using a question title as a prompt on search engines to find answers to screening questions.

While the actual question tiles are hidden from the candidates, it will be replaced with a generic title like Question 01, Question 02 etc.

You can also refer to our Proctoring Best Practice Guide for best results.

articles.name: Log In to HackerRank with Google Workspace Account
articles.title: Log In to HackerRank with Google Workspace Account
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank integrates with Google for Work to facilitate an easy and seamless remote interviewing experience.

As a part of this workflow, HackerRank users who have a Google for Work account can seamlessly log in to HackerRank without having to go through multiple steps of authenticating themselves into their HackerRank account. For example, remembering passwords, going through password managers, authenticating through SSO, and so on. This results in a hassle-free interview scheduling experience saving you a lot of time and effort.

Note: Google for Work integration does not work for the SSO integrations.

Prerequisites

  • You must have a predefined Google for Work account before you log in to the HackerRank account. 
  • You must have a work account for Google that you use for the HackerRank login.

Signing In to HackerRank Account with Google for Work Login

  1. Navigate to the HackerRank for Work Login page. The Google for work login is displayed along with the HackerRank login.
  2. Click Continue with Google to log in to your HackerRank account.

    The Choose an account page is displayed that shows all your Google for Work accounts.

  3. Select an account that you have already used to log in to HackerRank. It must be your work account. 

If you use an account that is not a work account, then an error is displayed:

Also, if the account is not valid, an error message is displayed as:

FAQs

If your company enforces login through SSO, you will not be authenticated based on your Google account. After you select your Google account for login, you will be redirected to your SSO provider.

articles.name: Screen Test: Common questions and best practice recommendations
articles.title: Screen Test: Common questions and best practice recommendations
articles.body:
Overview

This document presents various ways in which tests can be set up so that suitable candidates can be screened and shortlisted for a role. Below you’ll find essential questions with corresponding answers containing best practice recommendations.

 

What are the core/baseline skills the test should be assessing for? 

  • On breaking down the Job Description, identify 2-3 must-have skills needed for the job. 
  • It can be fundamentals that are essential for the role, which the Hiring Manager expects one to be proficient in, before the technical interview. (such as Problem Solving, Language Proficiency, Databases, etc.)
  • Structure the test with practical scenarios for the must-have skills as the main focus, and add multiple choice questions for the nice-to-have skills.

 

Will the test reports be reviewed by any Hiring Managers?

  • A HackerRank test can be set up in a fully automated fashion to evaluate and assess candidates.
  • We recommend that the Hiring Managers and their team create the assessment based on the evaluation criteria, leveraging the above point.
  • After performing benchmarking, the team can set a cut-off score which will automatically classify candidates as passed/failed.
  • The above approach and setup offloads the evaluation to the HackerRank platform, thus not requiring attention to individual test reports by the Hiring Manager.
  • However, they can still review and modify the score of a candidate as they see fit.

 

What should I do when my test questions get leaked?

  • Don’t assume just because a question is leaked suddenly everyone is going to get the answer correct. Many candidates do not look up answers during the assessment.
  • Check where the answer is leaked. A free site like Stack Overflow is different from a paid subscription where it’s a lot less likely a candidate will enroll mid-test to look up the answer.
  • Once a question is leaked, keep a close eye on the question scores going forward. If it starts to trend up then it’s a good sign to swap the question out.
  • Finally, if multiple candidates are looking up the question and using the answer, the plagiarism flag will start to be triggered more frequently and you’ll know they looked up the solution.
  • A leaked question doesn’t necessarily mean the solution is online too. There are cases where the problem statement is leaked but there is no solution available. Hence, check the leakage source.

 

What should the test set-up look like for a Software engineering role (Junior level)

  • Generally 2-3 coding questions of either increasing difficulty or spread across topics you’d like to assess (general coding, sql, basic linux, etc.)
  • Multiple Choice questions can also be used to test a wider range of skills and help with coding fatigue when candidates already have done a few strenuous questions.
  • Max time should be between 60-90 minutes for a junior role. Closer to 60 is probably better to ensure a higher completion rate.

 How do I ensure that I get a 60% pass rate in my test?

  • Continuously monitor and adjust the test. If after the first 50 candidates there’s a 20% pass rate, look at question difficulty, test length, candidate feedback.
  • There’s no set way to guarantee a 60% pass rate as every test and candidate pool is different. However, monitoring early test attempts closely and reacting quickly can ensure a 60% rate is reached. 
  • Write good test instructions and explain to the candidate what they should expect, what the test is about and why it is relevant. Good test instructions help to diminish the drop-off rate.

 

Why should I set a cut off score for my test? 

  • It helps ease the work of the employee assessing the candidates.
  • We highly recommend running enough tests before using a cut off.
  • Once there’s sufficient data and you’ve seen only candidates who get above X score get sent to the next stage of the interview process, then you can set a cut off so no one has to waste time looking at tests with scores below that number.

 

What should I benchmark my test?

  • There’s no set percentage to benchmark to, but it’s important early on to keep tabs on all the candidates and their scores and decide various benchmarks.
  • For example, you may have had 100 people take the test and sent them all to the next stage and saw that everyone who scored below a 50% was clearly not skilled enough. You can now set that 50% as a benchmark for pass/fail.
  • Similarly, you saw that anyone who scored above a 90% was extremely skilled and could qualify for a more senior role. You could set a benchmark for 50-90% pass and stick with the junior role, >90% pass and see if they’re a good fit for a senior role.

 

How do I know that my tests are comparable to my peers?

  • There’s no right or wrong test format, but the HackerRank team can look at your test and give advice.
  • Similarly, the HackerRank team can give you industry-wide numbers (such as average completion rate, pass rate, etc.) and you can see how the test compares to those and adjust accordingly.

 

What are best practices to achieve global test assessment standardization?

  • Standardization best practices deck here  

 

What are the factors to consider when benchmarking a test?

  • It is essential to get feedback from your internal test takers on several key factors:
    • Test Duration - Not too short, not too lengthy.
    • Question Difficulty - On par with the standard set by new employees hired for the same position.
    • Question Relevance - Alignment with the Job Description, and correlation with skills evaluated with respect to the role & experience level.
    • Question Type - Junior roles may require simple coding or MCQs but for senior folks, giving them a real world application development project makes more sense.

 

Can test instructions and invitations be customized?

  • Yes, test instructions and invitations can be customized and branded to improve the candidate experience.

 

How to create one test for different candidate pools (varying by experience level)?

  • Use a mix of MCQs and simple coding questions for junior candidates.
  • When it comes to mid level and senior candidates, use project based questions (Frontend, Backend and fullstack framework specific application development questions), system design questions and code review questions. 
  • In certain cases, skip the screen part and move on to the interviews platform directly for senior positions like tech lead, architects, SDMs and staff positions.

 

What are the best practices for proctoring the tests?

  • Refer here - Proctoring Best Practices

 

Can I add my own questions to the test?

  • Yes, you can add your own content onto the platform. This is your intellectual property and ONLY your company users can view and access this.
  • Refer here for more details - How to add custom questions 

 

What can I custom create on the HackerRank platform and what constraints are there?

  • You can create anything on the HackerRank platform if the answer to both following questions is YES: 
    • Are the libraries you want to use open source? 
    • Can your project run on a Docker image?

 

Can I restrict the language requirement for a particular assessment or question?

  • Yes you can. This can be done in 2 ways. You can set the language options for an entire test under test settings. This would apply for all the coding questions present in the test.
  • The other way is to restrict it question wise. To do this, you can clone a question and edit the language options there. 
  • Note : A language will be enabled for a question only if it's enabled at a test level and at the question level.

 

I want multiple tests with the same test settings and the majority of questions being the same; is this possible?

  • Yes, you can create one main test and have it as a template. 
  • Now, different teams can view that and clone it and make small changes as needed.
  • You can also lock the main test so that other teams don't edit it.

 

Is there a simple guide available highlighting all the skills and questions to use for assessing niche roles?

  • You can refer our skills directory for a quick brief about what skills and core competencies you can assess on the platform - Skills Directory
  • Apart from this, we also have detailed documents explaining the skills information, question types available to use, method of scoring and sample questions to use for a few roles as given below:
    • Data related roles - Document Link
    • Mobile roles (as of today) - Document Link

DevOps and Cloud roles - Document Link

articles.name: Mobile Development Questions in Interviews
articles.title: Mobile Development Questions in Interviews
articles.body:
Overview 

HackerRank interviews empower you to assess the mobile development (Android Java and Kotlin or React Native) skills of a candidate during interviews. A built-in emulator is provided inside the IDE for the interviewers and candidates to build and see their code in real-time. This article will walk you through the steps to use Mobile Developer questions in a HackerRank Interview.

Prerequisites

  • You must have scheduled a HackerRank interview, either by Quick pad or Scheduled Interview.

Steps to Import from Library

As of now, you can conduct the Mobile Developer interviews using two methods:

  1. Starting a project from scratch: This starts a new Android or React Native interview with a boilerplate code.
  2. Importing a project: You can import a project from a public Git URL or upload a zip file from your local system of size up to 5MB. 

Start from Scratch

  • Inside the interviews landing page, you can find the Mobile Development frameworks. Click on the desired tile from the available options: 
    • Android Java 
    • Android Kotlin 
    • React Native 

  • Select Start from Scratch on the next page.

  • This will launch the IDE with a basic code. You can further build on it based on your requirement.

  • You can check your progress while writing the code on the preview window placed on the left side of the interview screen. 

Import your Own Project 

  • To launch your own project you need to select the Import your Own Project option after selecting the framework.  

  • On the following page, you will be given two options.
    • Import from a public Git URL
    • Upload a Zip file as a source (Maximum file size allowed is up to 5MB) 
  • After proceeding with your desired choice give the project a name and click on Validate and Continue.    

  • After validating the project IDE will be launched where you can build your application further.  
  • Upon successful uploading, the project will be saved in interviews, and you can find it in the Recently Used tab.

articles.name: Accessing the HackerRank Academy
articles.title: Accessing the HackerRank Academy
articles.body:
Learn how to access the HackerRank Academy with on-demand learning paths and courses to assist you and your hiring teams learn about the functionality available in the HackerRank for Work Platform.

What is the HackerRank Academy?

The HackerRank Academy is a learning opportunity for organizations working with the HackerRank Platform. The academy is a resource for new and existing users to learn how to navigate and utilize the HackerRank Platform, along with best practices and guidance to other helpful HackerRank resources. The learning paths and courses available within the academy are segmented into bite-sized pieces, where users can return and pick up wherever they left off. Learn how to get up and running with HackerRank and spend less time reviewing resumes and more time interviewing high-quality candidates.

How can the HackerRank Academy be accessed?

  1. Through the HackerRank Academy URL, you'll be asked to provide your name and work email address.
  2. Through the HackerRank Platform (instructions below)
    • Log in to the HackerRank for Work Platform.
    • Click on the Academy Link at the bottom of the screen. (As highlighted in the image below)
    • Enjoy the available courses and learning paths!

articles.name: Setting up HackerRank Single Sign-On with Azure AD
articles.title: Setting up HackerRank Single Sign-On with Azure AD
articles.body:
Overview

SSO (Single Sign-on) on HackerRank for Work can be configured using efficient and productive Identity providers such as Azure AD.

You can log in to HackerRank through Azure AD. Create, update, and deactivate user accounts through SCIM 2.0.

Prerequisites

  • Obtain your SSO Unique ID by referring to the Getting Started with Single Sign-On
  • Replace the ID in the URLs below where you find: "YOURSSOUNIQUEID"
  • Keep these URLs available for the setup.
    • Entity ID https://www.hackerrank.com/x/api/v1/sso/saml/YOURSSOUNIQUEID/metadata
    • ACS/Reply URL - https://www.hackerrank.com/x/api/v1/sso/saml/YOURSSOUNIQUEID/acs
    • Sign-on URL - https://hackerrank.com/work/home
    • Logout URL - https://www.hackerrank.com/x/api/v1/sso/saml/YOURSSOUNIQUEID/logout

Note:  HackerRank accepts only the user's email address. HackerRank SSO fails if it receives anything other than an email address.

Configuring the SSO on Azure

  1. Navigate to the customer's Azure Portal: https://portal.azure.com
  2. Goto Enterprise Applications -> New Application.
  3. Click Create your own application. Add a name to the app.
  4. Select Integrate any other application you don't find in the gallery (Non-gallery).
  5. Click Set up single sign-on (Located on the left pane) -> SAML.
  6. Using the URLs from step 1 (Seen above), you can either create and upload a metadata file and then upload or manually enter the URLs from step 1 of the instructions as seen in step 7.
  7. If metadata has been uploaded, ensure the Identity ID, Reply URL, Logout URL, and
    Sign-on URLs are correct.
  8. If you are entering the URLs manually, click Edit on Basic SAML Configuration and enter the URLs from step 1 manually.
  9. Click to save.
  10. Verify the attributes as the sample below. 
    Download the Federation Metadata XML.
  11. Upload the metadata file to HackerRank.

Adding Users to the Group

  • This step varies from organization to organization, depending on their security policy.
  • You can click on Users and Groups and add users or groups to provide access to this app.

Testing the SSO Integration

The SSO integration can be tested in two ways:

  • Copying the HackerRank SSO Link from Step 2, and trying it in a private or incognito window.
  • Clicking Enable SSO and test the single sign-on from the Azure Portal.

Note: For the second way of testing on the Azure Portal, ensure that you do not close the SSO page while testing. In case the setup is not successful, you can disable SSO on the same page.

References

  • Configuring SAML Single Single Sign-On (SSO) for Azure AD Users
  • Tutorial: Azure Active Directory single sign-on (SSO) integration with OpenAthens - Microsoft Entra
  • Quickstart: Add an enterprise application  - Microsoft Entra

articles.name: Observation Mode in Interviews
articles.title: Observation Mode in Interviews
articles.body:
Overview

Observation Mode in HackerRank Interviews lets the interviewer keep an eye on what is happening on the candidate’s screen. This feature works like screen sharing where you as an interviewer can observe a candidate’s progress in real-time. The process to utilize the Observation Mode has been explained below.  

Using the Observation Mode

Starting the Observation Mode

  • Click on the candidate’s name on the interview screen and select the Observe Candidate button.
  • Once you enter the Observation Mode you will be indicated with a colored outline on your screen.

Key Features of Observation Mode 

  • After starting the Observation Mode the candidate’s screen will be mirrored on your screen and you will be able to observe their progress.
  • Your screen will move according to the candidate’s actions on their screen.  
  • If the candidate goes to the Input/Output tabs or clicks on the Run Code the same will be mirrored on your screen.
  • While in the Observation Mode you can use the Scorecard and chat functions as usual without ending the Observation Mode. You can also open the question description while Observation Mode is active. 

Things to Keep a Note

  • Currently, the feature works anonymously for the interviewer. Candidates will not be notified that they are being observed. 
  • The Observation Mode will work independently in case of multiple interviewers are present in an interview. Each interviewer can choose to use the Observation Mode or not and it will not affect the other interviewers' experience.  
  • If the candidate opens the question description section while in the Observation Mode it will not be mirrored. 
  • The Observation Mode currently works only for the coding questions. If you have multiple types of questions on your interview and the candidate moves to a non-coding question then you will be moved out of the Observation Mode.
  • If the candidate is working on a non-coding question you will not get the option to turn on the Observation Mode.
  • In case the candidate gets disconnected from the interview or becomes idle, you will be moved out of Observation Mode.  

Ending the Observation Mode 

  • If you want to end the Observation Mode there are two ways to do that:
    • You can click anywhere on the code editor and you will be moved out of the Observation Mode. 
    • You can click on the candidate’s name and select the Exit Observation button.

articles.name: Front-End Questions in HackerRank Interviews
articles.title: Front-End Questions in HackerRank Interviews
articles.body:
Overview 

HackerRank Interviews contains Front-end frameworks, Angular and React.

Candidates can work on a highly responsive, stable, and familiar editor to solve the Front-end questions, without worrying about getting familiar with a new editor or platform disruptions during the interview session.

Initiating Interviews with the Front-end Frameworks

  1. After you are logged into an interview as an interviewer, you can start the Front-end interview from the Interview landing page by clicking on the Front-end framework.

You can refer to this video to get started with the Front-End Interviews.

  • Select Angular or React frameworks to start an interview based on that framework.
  • The screen navigates to display three options to start a Front-end interview.
  • Select one of these three options:
    • Start from Scratch
    • Import Questions from Library
    • Import your own Project

Start from Scratch

HackerRank Interviews provides a simple project for you as a starting point in this option. You can modify the project before or during the interview to suit your needs.
Experience the new containerless VS Code IDE results in a faster loading and stable IDE that works with seamless unstable network connections. Developers can have faster and more accurate autocomplete when coding.

Enhanced IDE Features

  • Built-In Real-time Preview
    • The IDE opens with a built-in preview window on the right pane. Any changes made by you or the candidate can be seen on the Preview tab.
    • As the IDE is containerless, you can view the preview in a browser. Click the browser icon to view the preview in a browser.
    • You can also select a responsive view (tablet, mobile, desktop, and so on) for the preview. Click the icon to view the responsive view.
  • Test Execution
    • You can run the test cases by clicking the Test tab. Click the Run Tests option. The output is displayed.
  • Built-in Dev Tools  
    • The Dev Tools are available in the lower part of the Preview pane. You can click on the Dev Tools option for the respective framework and launch the console.  
    • The console works as a collaborative tool. The interviewer and the candidate can see their changes in real time.
  • Dependency Manager
    • On the left pane of the IDE, you can find the Dependencies search bar by clicking the cube icon. You can search for your desired dependencies and add them by clicking on add. Dependencies added are updated in the package.json file.
  • External CSS and Javascript Support
    • The External Resources is present on the left pane. Enter the URL of the external CSS and JavaScript resources in the External Resources address to format and style the UI.
  • Other UI Enhancements

You can view the other enhancements in the UI that are based on the VS Code Editor in the following clip.

Import From Question Library

This option takes you to the Library section in the Interviews. Here you can select a question from HackerRank Library or a question created by your company inside HackerRank Library.

Click Use to launch the question along with the IDE. The IDE launches.

Import Your Project

This option allows you to select your own starter code for interviews by uploading your own project zip file or adding it from a public Git URL. Save the project with an appropriate name to retrieve it in the subsequent interviews. After you import, the projects load in HackerRank’s Projects IDE.

Note: The maximum file size allowed for the project is 5MB. This flow does not get the new IDE features. This flow is currently in beta.

Once you have uploaded a project, you can find it in the Recently Used section on the landing page whenever you start a new interview.

articles.name: DevOps Questions in HackerRank Interviews
articles.title: DevOps Questions in HackerRank Interviews
articles.body:
Overview

You can use DevOps questions inside HackerRank interviews. With this feature, interviewers can assess the Linux skills of a candidate during live interviews. This article will walk you through the steps to import DevOps questions in HackerRank Interview. 

Steps to Use DevOps Questions in Interviews.  

Here is a simple walkthrough video that elaborates the process

Or, if you prefer to follow directions, here are the steps for your ready reference.

  • Once you are inside the interview, click on the DevOps tile on the interview landing page.

  • You will see two options.

    • Start from Scratch: You can utilize a powerful bare shell terminal on an Ubuntu18 server to install any tool and work on a diverse set of tasks during an interview.

    • Import Question From Library: This option takes you to the Library section inside the Interviews platform. You can choose from more than 100 ready-made DevOps questions from the HackerRank library. Click on the Use button beside it to launch the terminal.

    • You can also choose from DevOps questions created by you or shared with you by your HackerRank team members. Click on the Use button to launch the terminal.

  • Once the interview starts, you can monitor the candidate’s progress on the task on your screen. Whatever the candidate types inside the terminal will be visible to you in real-time. 
  • As an interviewer, you can also access the same terminal to guide the candidate or to modify the task. 

An alternative way to import questions in the interview is through the Question Library tile, where you can select the Type filter to DevOps. 

 

Note: HackerRank Interviews does not support questions using the older versions of operating systems such as Ubuntu 14 and RHEL 7

Once the interview is over, you can view the session recording in the Interview Reports while taking notes and feedback on the scorecard.

articles.name: Zoom - HackerRank Interview Integration
articles.title: Zoom - HackerRank Interview Integration
articles.body:
Overview

You can access HackerRank Interview’s online code editor that mirrors the environment you are used to working in, while also being packed with powerful hiring features inside the Zoom application. 

How it Works

This article will walk you through the workflow of Interviews inside Zoom.  

  • First Install the HackerRank app from the Zoom marketplace. 
  • Now start a new meeting inside the Zoom application.  
  • At the bottom of the space, click on the Apps button. 

  • As you have already installed the HackerRank application, you can find it inside the Apps window under the My Apps section. Click on the app title to launch HackerRank Interviews.

Note: If you are yet to download the app you can do so from the Discover section inside the Apps window.  

  •  HackerRank Interviews will be launched inside Zoom as a separate application.

  • Click on the Invite button and select a participant from the list to start the interview with them.

  • You can then select the interview of your choice and work on it collaboratively.
  • You can also use the Share Screen feature from the Interviews window, as shown below.
  • To blur your background during the interview, select the Apply Background Blur option available in the audio video calls option, as shown. Note that you can use the blur background option for Zoom only on the Chrome and Edge browsers.
  • Once done, you can close the Interviews window by clicking on the three dots icon at the top right corner and selecting Close. 

Note: You can only use the free version of HackerRank Interviews, as it is not possible to log in with your HackerRank account inside the Zoom application as of now. Also, currently, we only support 1:1 interviews, and no more than two participants can use the interview application at a time. 

Mask Information on Zoom Recordings

HackerRank ensures data confidentiality by encrypting and securely masking PII (Personally Identifiable Information) transmitted to Zoom. You can opt to have Interviewer and Candidate names masked in the Zoom video recordings. The candidate’s name is displayed as “Candidate” and Interviewer name is displayed as ‘Interviewer.’ 

Note: Interview recording is an opt-in feature. You can reach out to your account manager or HackerRank support (support@hackerrank.com) to enable it. 

For more information on how to use HackerRank Interviews or to sign up for a HackerRank account, visit here

Key Features

  1. Access to the library: Select any available question from the HackerRank library. Questions are written based on role, skill, and difficulty.
  2. Code Editor and Programming Languages: The interview interface has a built-in code editor which supports more than 40 programming languages. These are available in the drop-down menu in the top right corner of the page. You can change the language for each question. However, if you have disabled certain languages during question creation, then you can choose only enabled languages.
  3. Code collaboration: All participants in the interview can edit code, provide input, and test code by running it live on our platform. The interviewer can monitor the changes made by the candidate in real-time.
  4. Run Tests: This will run all test cases, and the output of the same will be shown in the 'Output' tab.
  5. Run Code: This will run the code for the current input in the input tab, and the output of the same will be shown in the 'Output' tab.
  6. Built-in Whiteboard: The virtual whiteboard tool lets candidates and interviewers sketch diagrams using easy tools from the toolbar.
  7. Notes: Take notes that are not visible to the candidate. These notes can be shared with the other team members during the evaluation and decision-making process.

Click here to learn more about how to set up your interview and use all the key features.

articles.name: Conducting Events copy
articles.title: Conducting Events copy
articles.body:
Overview

Container-based real-world Projects questions are great at testing a candidate’s knowledge of frameworks and skills in building real applications. Candidates get access to an IDE that provides features similar to development-level IDE. 

Tests with Front End, Back End, Full-Stack, Data Science, and DevOps questions will have this experience.

However, containers introduce some scaling limitations at a customer company level. These limitations are important to provide a good candidate experience.

The scaling limitation for each question type is mentioned in the following table:  

Question Type Logins Per Minute  Concurrent Sessions 
Front-end 30 500
Back-end 30 500
Full stack 30 500
Data Science  30 500
DevOps  20 100

Inviting candidates in bulk to Projects Tests

  • If you expect your candidates to login in a staggered manner, you can go ahead and invite all the candidates. There should not be any negative candidate experience.
  • If you expect all the candidates to log in at once or if your test starts at a particular time
    • Candidates might see a prompt to wait for some time when they reach the threshold mentioned in the table above. (Check candidate experience section for more details)
    • To mitigate this situation, it is recommended that you invite candidates in batches.
  • If inviting candidates in batches is not an option, please reach out to your customer success manager or write to us at support@hackerrank.com for additional support and options.
  • If you expect more candidates than the given limit to take the test in parallel, please reach out to us through support@hackerrank.com to inquire about temporary increases in capacity to support your event.

Candidate experience in events with Projects tests

  1. The first 30 candidates will be provisioned servers for the test and will be able to start the test. In the case of the DevOps questions, the number is 20.
  2. All remaining candidates will see a prompt saying, “We are seeing unusually high traffic. We are trying to provision a server for your test. Try again after the countdown below.” They will see a timer for a minute before they can retry logging into the test.
  3. After the first minute, the next set of candidates will be provisioned servers and so on. 
  4. If the candidates in a session exceed the limit, the first set of candidates will be logged in to the test, the next set of candidates will see an error: “Our servers are at capacity. Please try to take this test after some time”. As existing candidates finish their attempts, new candidates will be allowed to log into the test.

articles.name: Font in Interview's Dark Mode  is Black. How Can I Change it?
articles.title: Font in Interview's Dark Mode  is Black. How Can I Change it?
label_names: How To change font color in HackerRank Interviews
How to change font color in dark mode
articles.body:
At times it is possible that you get the black font in dark mode Interviews if you are using a Mac OS device. There are two solutions to this issue.  

Solution A

  • Open the font book and search for Source Code Pro. 
  • Now right-click on the Source Code Pro and select disable the Source Code Pro family and select Disable from the popup. 

  • Download the Source Code Pro family from the Google fonts store. 
  • Install the Source Code Pro family as shown in the below screenshots.  

  • Refresh the interview page once the installation is completed. It will show the colored font as usual. 

Solution B

This problem usually occurs when you are using any third-party browsers in Mac OS devices. Opening the interview in the Safari browser should solve the problem.

articles.name: Project Questions

articles.body:
HackerRank Projects enables you to create Project-based questions to assess candidates. articles.name: Getting Started for Hiring Managers
articles.title: Getting Started for Hiring Managers
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank is a hiring platform that helps companies seamlessly hire skilled developers in a remote-first environment. As a technical recruiter or hiring manager, you can use HackerRank's Developer Skills Platform to objectively evaluate tech talent at every stage of your company's recruiting process. Here is a guide to help you get started with the HackerRank platform.

The Developer skills Platform is designed around four core components of the hiring process that will help you hire the right candidate for a job role.

  • Plan 
  • Screen
  • Interview
  • Rank

Plan

Planning is critical in any hiring process and in the remote first work environment, a proper hiring plan has become more important than ever. Whether you are hiring recent university grads or experienced professionals, you can use our platform to customize roles and examinations to meet your specific hiring needs and effectively assess the right skills for the job thus experiencing an excellent candidate hiring experience.

Choosing the Right Skills for a Role

The Roles Management module in the HackerRank for Work platform is designed to give more control and structure to the hiring process. The HackerRank Skills Directory hosts a set of skills along with key competencies based on Industry standards vetted by the HackerRank Skills Advisory Council. You can create Roles and map them to specific skills that meet the requirements for the Role. 

Supporting Articles

  • Getting Started with Roles and Skills
  • How to create Custom Roles on HackerRank

Screen

We provide you with end-to-end screening options to accelerate your hiring process and save time wasted in reviewing huge volumes of resumes. The screening process involves Tests and interviews, which are discussed below in detail. 

Picking the Right Question 

The HackerRank library offers you a wide range of ready-made questions with different levels of complexity across various programming languages. You can use these questions in your assessments and evaluate your candidates for a specific role. You can find these ready-to-use questions in our library under ‘HackerRank Questions’. Further, if you want to use custom questions in your tests, you can create questions from the library. Custom questions are saved in “My Company Questions” in the library. 

Hassle-free Question Search  

You can use the filter option in the HackerRank library to easily skim through the available questions. Select the job role from the drop-down and use various filters like skills, difficulty, recommended time, owner, etc to find the right set of questions and use them in your test

Supporting Articles

  • HackerRank Library Navigation

Creating Assessment for your Role 

As a hiring manager, you can create online assessments to assess candidates for various roles.

You can either create a predefined test on specific roles or create your own questions and add them to your custom tests. You can also filter tests from the test dashboard based on Labels, Owners, Roles, and Work Experience. 

Here is a video on how to create a test in HackerRank.

Supporting Articles

Creating a New test

 

Supporting Article

  • Creating a New test

Know your Candidates Performance

Inside a test, you will get the reporting and insights features that help you gain perspective into how your Candidates are performing in their Tests and also analyze the Test efficiency in hiring the right talent. The detailed test report gives you a comprehensive view of the submitted answers, code solutions, automatically evaluated scores, test case execution statuses, logs, etc. The detailed test report also offers code quality checks and plagiarism detectors to help you classify Candidates who provide genuine solutions in your Tests. 

You can download candidate reports in the form of PDFs or excels.

Supporting Articles

  • Test Insights
  • Viewing a Candidates Detailed Test Report
  • Downloading PDF and Excel Test Reports
  • Plagiarism Detection

Interviews 

The HackerRank Interview platform lets you conduct effective technical interviews with candidates remotely in a real-time coding environment. You can leverage a library of 2,100+ questions and schedule 1:1 or panel interviews with candidates who have passed the previous rounds of the hiring process. Here are some of the key features of HackerRank Interview.

  • Virtual Lobby: With panel interviews with candidates, it becomes essential to ensure that the participants inside the interview are not disturbed by the sudden appearance of others. The virtual lobby feature inside HackerRank Interviews helps you deal with this challenge. Learn More.
  • Built-in IDE: To support as many languages as possible and assist you with the ability to evaluate the candidate as per your job requirements, we have a user-friendly built-in IDE. This built-in IDE supports more than 40 languages. 
  • Integration with Test: Import questions from the Screen stage and iterate on them together in real-time. This feature gives you an opportunity to review the code with the candidate in real-time, ask questions, and better understand the candidate’s approach to problem-solving. You can also import questions from the library or use custom questions during the interview. Learn More.
  • Recommended Questions: To make interviews seamless and efficient, we also provide Recommended Questions within the “Import Question” section which offer a set of questions specially designed for interviews and these questions usually take less than 30 mins to solve and are designed to have a quick read time (~5 mins). Learn More
  • Interviewer Scorecard: You can access the Interviewer Scorecard during an interview to manually evaluate the candidate you are interviewing. The interviewer scorecard is a private scorecard that displays a set of skills to be analyzed based on the role that the candidate is getting hired for. Learn More.
  • Virtual Whiteboard: To elevate the remote interviewing experience, a collaborative virtual whiteboard is also integrated into our interviewing platform. Learn More.
  • Interview Template: We ensure a consistent and structured interview process with no bias, by adding Interview templates. These templates assist you to set the same questions for all the candidates applying for a particular role. Learn More.

Rank

You can rank your candidates in HackerRank based on Code Quality, Problem Solving, Language Proficiency, and Technical Communication. Review candidate scores and integrated candidate packets across the entire hiring process. Benchmark results against your candidate pool and the HackerRank developer community to deliver even more confidence in your hiring decision.

Candidate Packet 

HackerRank captures every touchpoint throughout the entire hiring process and presents the same in an integrated Candidate Packet that summarizes all the data on the candidate’s technical skills. It provides you with a holistic view of the candidate’s performance. 

Inside the candidate packet, HackerRank provides you with options for benchmarking. It assists you in comparing the performance of a candidate for a specific skill against the cohort of candidates who have been assessed on the same skill sets. 

Supporting Articles

  • Candidate Packet in HackerRank
  • Benchmarking Inside Candidate Packets

articles.name: Viewing Question Insights
articles.title: Viewing Question Insights
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank provides insights into every question, which will help the recruiters to analyze the performance of each question under multiple parameters. Various fields in the insights will help you understand the candidates’ approach and success rate in solving a particular question. Using this analysis you can select suitable questions for your test.  

Steps to View Question Insights

Prerequisites

  • The question must be used at least once in a test.  

Steps

  • Navigate to the library and hover your mouse over the required question. 
  • Click on the Insights option to view the Question Insights page.

There are multiple sections on the insights page which are described below. 

Details 

This section provides the details related to the question like when it was created, who created the question, the Score of the question, and the recommended time to answer the question.   

Stat

This section provides information such as the number of attempts made to answer this question, Median Score, Median Attempt Time, and Median Time to Full Score. You can hover over the info icons to know the definition of these terms.

Median Score: 50% of the candidates who attempted the question scored less than or equal to the number mentioned.  

Median Attempt Time: 50% of the candidates who attempted this question took less than or equal to the time mentioned. 

Median Time to Full Score: 50% of the candidates who scored 100% answering this question took less than or equal to the time mentioned.

Note: On the right corner of the page you can filter if you want to see the insights for All Tests or custom tests. 

Score Distribution

The score distribution graph elaborates the Distribution of the score percentage of candidates who attempted a response to this question.

Usage Over Time 

Usage over time graphs explains how many candidates attempted to answer this question per month from its inception to the date.

Note: Hover your mouse over the graph to see exact numbers. 

Candidates by Language 

The pie chart under the candidates by language section shows the percentage of candidates to answer this question based on language.

Note: you can use the arrow marks to see the list of languages. 

Language Stats 

This section shows a statistical table of Candidates by language and the Median Score, Maximum Score Attained, and Median Time Taken.

Note: You can click on each section name in the table to sort the values to start from either higher or lower.   

Using these stats and graphs in question insights recruiters can select which question will be suitable for their tests.
